item.title: Panama City Beach with My 70-Pound Dog: Embassy Suites Review
item.description:
Last month, Ansel and I made the drive from Jacksonville to Panama City Beach for a long weekend. I’d been eyeing the Embassy Suites by Hilton Panama City Beach Resort for a while ‚Äî it’s pet-friendly, right across from the beach, and I had a stack of Hilton points burning a hole in my account. Here’s how it went.

Someone approved of the room upgrade.

The Booking

I used my Hilton Honors American Express Surpass points plus a free night certificate to book this stay. I stayed for 5 nights ‚Äî and here’s a tip: when you book 4 nights with points, the 5th night is free. That’s a 20% discount built right in.

The only thing I actually paid out of pocket? Tipping the valet. That’s it.

Pet fees: $75 for stays of 1-4 nights, or $125 for 5+ nights. They allow up to 2 pets, max 75 lbs each, dogs and cats only. No breed restrictions. Ansel is a 70-pound German Shorthaired Pointer/Lab mix, so he squeaked in under the limit.

Pro tip: If you have Hilton Diamond status, request a room upgrade when you book. I asked and got bumped to a king suite with an ocean view and a balcony. Ansel spent a solid 20 minutes every morning just watching the beach from up there.

(New to points and hotel status? Check out my guide to the best credit cards for pet travelers and how Hilton Diamond status works.)

The Hotel: What You Need to Know

The Embassy Suites PCB is located right by Pier Park, across the street from the beach. Not beachfront, but close enough that it’s a 5-minute walk to sand. In fact, everything we did ‚Äî Dog Beach, Pier Park, Margaritaville ‚Äî was within walking distance of the hotel. We barely moved the car all week.

Here’s the thing nobody tells you: there’s only one elevator.

If you’re traveling with a dog ‚Äî especially a bigger one who needs to go out first thing in the morning ‚Äî request a room close to the elevator. I didn’t think to ask, and our first morning involved a very long hallway walk with an increasingly urgent pup. Lesson learned.

Making himself at home.

The room itself was spacious (it’s a suite, so you get a separate living area), clean, and the balcony was a huge win. Ansel could hang out there while I got ready without feeling cooped up.

The hotel also has designated dog areas around the property with poop bag stations, so those early morning and late night potty breaks are easy.

Note: Dogs are not allowed at the pool. If you want pool time, you’ll need to plan around it (more on that below).

The Beach

The big draw here is Dog Beach ‚Äî an exclusive dog beach right across from Pier Park. You can see the “Welcome to Dog Beach” sign from Margaritaville. It’s a short walk from the hotel.

The destination.

First time touching PCB sand.

That Gulf water is unreal.

Dog-Friendly Dining

One of the best parts of PCB is how many restaurants have dog-friendly patios ‚Äî and most of them are walking distance from the hotel. We hit up Margaritaville ‚Äî great views, Ansel got tons of attention, and they didn’t bat an eye at a 70-pound dog under the table.

Lunch with a view.

He was very well-behaved (mostly).

Exploring Pier Park

Pier Park is a huge outdoor shopping area right next to the hotel ‚Äî literally a few minutes walk. Lots of stores, restaurants, and photo ops. Ansel found his way onto a Ron Jon surfboard.

Surfer pup.

Road Trip Essentials: What I Packed

A few things that made the drive with a 70-pound dog way easier:

  • Backseat cover ‚Äî Protects the seats, gives Ansel a non-slip surface, and makes cleanup a breeze.
  • Travel water bottle with bowl ‚Äî Attaches right to a cup holder. Perfect for rest stops.
  • Poop bags ‚Äî I always overpack. Running out at a hotel is not the move.

(For my full packing list, check out road trip essentials for traveling with your dog.)

Need a Break? Daycare & Grooming Options

Sometimes you want to hit the pool or grab dinner somewhere that isn’t dog-friendly. Here are your options near the hotel:

  • ZOOMIES Pet Hotel ‚Äî Full daycare, boarding, and grooming. Book ahead, especially on weekends.
  • Dagny and Dexter’s ‚Äî Another solid daycare option nearby.
  • PetSmart in Pier Park ‚Äî Right next door for grooming or supplies. I dropped Ansel off here for a grooming session so I could spend a few hours at the pool.

I’d recommend booking daycare in advance if you know you’ll want pool time or want to explore without the dog for a day.

The Verdict

This was a genuinely easy trip. The hotel is well-located for a dog-friendly beach weekend, the points redemption felt like good value, and Ansel had a blast.

Would I go back? Yeah, probably. Next time I’ll be smarter about requesting a room near the elevator, and I’ll book daycare in advance so I can get more pool time.

Ansel’s Rating: 4/5 Paws üêæüêæüêæüêæ

What he loved: The balcony. The beach. All the new smells at Pier Park.

What he didn’t love: That long hallway walk at 6am.

Quick Reference

Detail Info
Hotel Embassy Suites by Hilton Panama City Beach Resort
Location Across from beach, next to Pier Park
Pet Policy 2 pets max, 75 lbs each, dogs/cats only, no breed restrictions
Pet Fee $75 (1-4 nights) or $125 (5+ nights)
Points Used Hilton Honors (via Surpass card + free night cert)
Out of Pocket Valet tip only
Dog-Friendly Beach Dog Beach, walking distance
Dog Areas On-site with poop bag stations
Pool No dogs allowed ‚Äî use grooming/daycare for pool time
Grooming PetSmart in Pier Park
Daycare ZOOMIES Pet Hotel, Dagny and Dexter’s (book ahead!)
Room Tip Request a room near the elevator

item.title: Road Trip Essentials for Traveling with Your Dog
item.description:
I’ve done enough road trips with Ansel to know what’s actually worth packing ‚Äî and what just takes up space. Here’s my go-to list for traveling with a 70-pound dog.

Car Setup

Seat cover ‚Äî Non-negotiable. I use one in my 4Runner that covers the entire back seat, has flaps that protect the doors, and is waterproof. Saves your interior from muddy paws, sand, and the occasional drool puddle.

Crate or barrier ‚Äî If your dog does better contained, a crash-tested crate is the safest option. Brands like Gunner and Ruff Land are pricey but built to protect your dog in an accident. If a crate doesn’t fit your setup, a car barrier keeps them in the back without roaming into the front seat.

Seat belt harness ‚Äî Another safety option if you don’t use a crate. Clips into your seatbelt and keeps your dog secured.

Food & Water

Travel water bottle with bowl attachment ‚Äî This is the one thing I’d never skip. Mine has a bowl that screws onto the top, so I can give Ansel water at rest stops without digging through bags. Fits right in the cup holder.

Collapsible bowls ‚Äî Cheap, packable, and useful for food or water at the hotel.

Food storage ‚Äî I portion out food into ziplock bags or use a small airtight container. Keeps things simple and avoids lugging an entire bag of kibble.

Comfort Items

Pet blanket ‚Äî Ansel has a designated travel blanket. It smells like home, which helps him settle in unfamiliar hotel rooms. Also useful for covering hotel furniture if you’re worried about fur.

Favorite toy ‚Äî Something familiar to keep them occupied during downtime.

Treats ‚Äî For rewarding good behavior, training moments, and bribing them back into the car after a rest stop.

Safety & Cleanup

Poop bags ‚Äî I always overpack. Running out at a hotel or rest stop is not a situation you want to be in.

Pet first aid kit ‚Äî Basic stuff: bandages, antiseptic wipes, tweezers for ticks, Benadryl (ask your vet for dosage). You probably won’t need it, but you’ll be glad you have it.

Towels ‚Äî At least one or two. For wet paws, muddy adventures, or unexpected messes.

Lint roller ‚Äî Your future self will thank you.

Documents

Vaccination records ‚Äî Some hotels ask for proof of rabies vaccination. Keep a copy on your phone or in the car.

ID tags ‚Äî Make sure your dog’s tags are up to date with your current phone number.

Microchip info ‚Äî Know your microchip number and make sure your contact info is current in the registry.

The Short List

If you’re in a hurry, here’s the minimum:

  • Seat cover
  • Water bottle with bowl
  • Poop bags
  • Blanket
  • Treats
  • Leash (obviously)
  • Vaccination records

Everything else is nice to have but not essential for a weekend trip.

Where I’ve Used This Stuff

Most recently, Ansel and I did 5 nights in Panama City Beach ‚Äî about a 5-hour drive from Jacksonville. This packing list kept us covered the whole trip.

Have a road trip essential I missed? Let me know ‚Äî I’m always looking to upgrade my setup.

item.title: Best Credit Cards for Pet Travelers (2025)
item.description:
If you travel with your dog and aren’t using hotel credit cards, you’re leaving money on the table. Pet fees, room rates, and all those extras add up fast ‚Äî but the right cards can offset most of it with points, free nights, and elite status perks.

Here’s what I use and recommend for pet travelers.

Why Hotel Cards Make Sense for Pet Owners

Most pet-friendly hotels charge $50‚Äì$150 per stay in pet fees. You can’t avoid those (yet), but you can make the room itself free by booking with points. And with elite status, you get perks like room upgrades, late checkout, and free breakfast ‚Äî all of which make traveling with a dog way easier.

I haven’t paid for a hotel room in years. I use Hilton points from my credit cards, and the free night certificates cover the rest.

My Setup: The Hilton Combo

I’m loyal to Hilton because their pet policies are solid (most properties allow dogs up to 75 lbs with no breed restrictions), and their credit cards are some of the best in the game.

Hilton Honors American Express Aspire

Annual fee: $550
Status: Automatic Diamond (the top tier)
Free nights: 1 per year, plus more at $30k and $60k spend
Sign-up bonus: 175,000 points after spending $6,000 in 6 months

This is the card if you’re serious about hotel travel. Diamond status gets you room upgrades, executive lounge access, and late checkout ‚Äî all super helpful when traveling with a dog.

That 175,000-point bonus alone is worth around 2‚Äì3 free nights at most Hilton properties. Combined with the annual free night certificate, you could have a week’s worth of hotel stays from day one.

Key perks:

  • Up to $400/year in Hilton resort credits ($200 every 6 months)
  • Up to $200/year in flight credits ($50/quarter)
  • Up to $209/year CLEAR credit
  • $100 credit at Waldorf Astoria and Conrad properties
  • 14x points at Hilton, 7x on dining and flights, 3x everything else

How the $550 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value
Annual free night certificate $300+
Hilton resort credits $400
Flight credits $200
CLEAR credit $209
Total $1,100+

Even if you only use half of these, you’re coming out ahead. I use the resort credits on room charges during Hilton stays and the flight credits stack up over the year without thinking about it.

Hilton Honors American Express Surpass

Annual fee: $150
Status: Automatic Gold (Diamond if you spend $40k/year)
Free nights: 1 after spending $15k in a calendar year
Sign-up bonus: 155,000 points after spending $3,000 in 6 months

This is the sweet spot for most travelers. Gold status gets you the 5th night free on award stays, plus a daily food & beverage credit or free breakfast at most properties.

The sign-up bonus is easier to hit than the Aspire ($3k vs $6k), and 155,000 points is still enough for multiple free nights.

Key perks:

  • Up to $200/year in Hilton credits ($50/quarter)
  • 12x points at Hilton, 6x on dining/groceries/gas, 3x everything else
  • Free night after $15k spend

How the $150 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value
Quarterly Hilton credits $200
Total $200

Just by using the $50 quarterly credit on any Hilton purchase (room charges, dining at the hotel, etc.), you’re $50 ahead before you even count the points you’re earning. If you hit the $15k spend for the free night certificate, that’s another $200+ in value.

I carry both the Aspire and Surpass. Between them, I get 2‚Äì3 free night certificates per year, plus enough points from everyday spending to cover several more nights.

Hilton Honors American Express (No Annual Fee)

Annual fee: $0
Status: Silver
Sign-up bonus: 100,000 points after spending $2,000 in 6 months

If you’re just getting started, this is a no-risk way to begin earning Hilton points. You won’t get a free night certificate, but you still get the 5th night free benefit on award stays, which is a 20% discount on any points redemption of 5+ nights.

100,000 points for just $2,000 in spending ‚Äî with no annual fee ‚Äî is one of the best entry points into hotel rewards. No fee means nothing to justify.

Key perks:

  • 7x points at Hilton, 5x on dining/groceries/gas, 3x everything else
  • No annual fee
  • 5th night free on award stays

The Alternative: Marriott

If you prefer Marriott properties, the Marriott Bonvoy Boundless card is solid.

Annual fee: $95
Status: Silver Elite (Gold at $35k spend)
Free nights: 1 per year (worth up to 35,000 points, can top off with 15k more)
Sign-up bonus: 3 free nights (each worth up to 50,000 points) after spending $3,000 in 3 months

That sign-up bonus is huge ‚Äî 3 free nights at properties up to 50,000 points each. That could cover a long weekend at a solid Marriott property right out of the gate.

Key perks:

  • Up to 17x points at Marriott properties
  • 3x on dining, groceries, and gas (first $6k/year)
  • Annual free night certificate
  • 15 Elite Night Credits per year

How the $95 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value
Annual free night certificate $200+
Total $200+

The free night certificate alone is worth at least double the annual fee at most Marriott properties. You can also top it off with up to 15,000 additional points to book nicer hotels.

Marriott’s pet policies vary more by property than Hilton’s, so always check before booking. Some Marriott brands (like Residence Inn and TownePlace Suites) tend to be more consistently pet-friendly.

Which Card Should You Get?

If you’re new to points: Start with the no-annual-fee Hilton card. The 100,000-point bonus for $2,000 spend is an easy win, and you can learn the system risk-free.

If you travel 2‚Äì4 times per year: The Hilton Surpass is the move. The $150 fee is more than covered by the $200 in quarterly Hilton credits.

If you travel frequently: Get the Hilton Aspire. Yes, it’s $550 ‚Äî but you get over $1,100 in credits and perks back. Diamond status is a game-changer for traveling with dogs ‚Äî upgrades to suites mean more space for everyone.

If you prefer Marriott: The Boundless card is a good value at $95/year. The annual free night alone makes it worth keeping.

How I Booked Panama City Beach for Free

For my recent 5-night trip to Panama City Beach, I used:

  • Hilton points (earned from my Surpass card)
  • A free night certificate (from my Aspire card)
  • The 5th night free benefit (book 4 nights with points, get the 5th free)

Total out of pocket for the room: $0

I still paid the $125 pet fee (5+ nights), but that’s a lot easier to stomach when the room was free.

Quick Comparison

Card Annual Fee Sign-Up Bonus Credits/Perks Free Night
Hilton Aspire $550 175k points $1,100+/year Yes (annual)
Hilton Surpass $150 155k points $200/year After $15k spend
Hilton (no fee) $0 100k points ‚Äî No
Marriott Boundless $95 3 free nights ‚Äî Yes (annual)

The Bottom Line

Pet travel gets expensive fast. The right credit cards won’t eliminate pet fees, but they can make the room free ‚Äî and that’s a huge win.

The annual fees on these cards look scary at first, but once you factor in the credits and free nights, most of them pay you back more than you put in. Start with whichever card fits your budget and travel frequency, and build from there.

I’ve been running this setup for years, and it’s saved me thousands. If you’re road tripping with your dog anyway, you might as well do it for free.

Questions about which card is right for you? Reach out ‚Äî happy to help.
